comment.author: 39639456@N00
comment._content: Can someone tell me what the Gaynor Notification means?

comment.author: 31580040@N04
comment._content: It seems to be part of the mayoral election campaign of 1913. The notification ceremonies took place on 3rd September 1913. William Gaynor, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Gaynor was nominated for mayor by a group of independent supporters after clashing with the Democrats over corruption in office. He died a few days after this on 10th September 1913. The C. F. M. of the placard will be Charles F Murphy, the boss of Tammany Hall.

comment.author: 45207146@N04
comment._content: why are there so many shovels on the ground?

comment.author: 34904489@N07
comment._content: Thanks to all for your helpful information. We will expand the description for this photograph as well as others from the Sept. 3, 1913 Gaynor notification ceremony. The notification ceremony was Gaynor accepting the nomination for re-election as New York's mayor on an independent ticket. The shovel was a symbol of his campaign, and this photograph shows the shovels carried by his supporters surrounding an epitaph of sorts to the election hopes of Charles F. Murphy. More about this day can be found in this article from the New York Times.
